chapter.title: Manage organisation units
chapter.para: In this section you will learn how to:

listitem.para: Create a new organisation unit and build up the organisation unit hierarchy
Create organisation unit groups, group sets, and assigning organisation units to them
Modify the organisation unit hierarchy

section.title: Organisation units overview
section.para: The organisation unit hierarchy defines the organisation structure of DHIS 2, for example how the health facilities, administrative areas and other geographical areas are arranged with respect to each other. It is the "where" dimension of DHIS 2, similar to how periods represent the "when" dimension. DHIS 2 is structured so that the organisation unit hierarchy is a geographical hierarchy, and the GIS app depends on this.

The organisation unit hierarchy is built up of parent-child relations. Each node in this hierarchy is called an organisation unit in DHIS 2. A country might for example have eight provinces, and each province might have a number of districts as children. Normally, the lowest levels consist of facilities where data is collected. Data collecting facilities can also be located at higher levels, for example national or provincial hospitals. Therefore, you can create skewed organisation trees in DHIS 2.

listitem.para: You can create additional classifiations by using organisation groups and organisation group sets, for example parallel administrative boundaries to the health care sector.
It is recommonedded to use organisation unit groups when you want to create a non-geographical hierarchy.
You can only have one organisation hierarchy at the same time.
You can have any number of levels in a hierarchy.
Typically national organisation hierarchies in public health have four to six levels.
An organisation unit can only be a member of a single organisation unit group within an organisation unit group set.

section.para: How you design the organisation unit hierarchy determines the geographical units that you can analyse after data collection and aggregation.
The design of the organisation unit hierarchy determines the geopraphical units of analysis available to the users as data is collected and aggregated in this structure.
The organisation unit hierarchy is the main vehicle for data aggregation on the geographical dimension.

important.title: Changing the organisation unit hierarchy
important.para: You can change the organisation unit hierarchy after you've created it, even organisaiton units that collect data. However, DHIS 2 always uses the latest organisation unit hierarchy for aggregation. So if you change the organisation unit hierarchy, the temporal representation of the organisation unit hierarchy across time is lost.

example.para: District A is sub-divided into District B and District C. Facilities which belonged to District A are reassigned to District B and C. Any historical data, which was entered before the split occurred, is still registered as belonging to District B and C, not to the obsolete District A.

section.para: In the Maintenance app, you can manage the following organisation unit objects:

table.title: Organisation unit objects in the Maintenance app

entry.para: Create, edit, clone, delete, show details and translate
Create, edit, clone, share, delete, show details and translate
Create, edit, clone, share, delete, show details and translate

section.title: Workflow
section.para: The recommended workflow is:

listitem.para: Create organsation units.
Create organisation unit groups.
Create organisation unit group sets.
Add organisation groups to organisation unit group sets.
Add organisation units to organisation unit groups.

section.para: To avoid such situations it is recommend to first add groups to group sets, and then organisation units to groups.
It is recommend that you approach the organisation unit grouping in the following sequence (and one group set at a time):

listitem.para: Define a new organisation unit group set, for example "Location".

Add new organisation unit groups (for example "Urban", "Rural" and "Peri-urban"). Once all groups have been defined, return to the organisation unit group set and assign each of the desired groups to the group set.

Go back to each group, one by one, go to edit mode and assign the organisation units that should be member of the group. Should you follow this route, you can place multiple organisation units at a time in a group. However, you must be careful not to place the same organisation units in two groups which itself is a member of an organisation unit group set. This will result in a data integrity violation. If you have organisation unit groups which are not exclusive, they should not be members of a group.

A better way to ensure that you do not mistakenly assign an organisation unit to multiple members of a group set is you can use the edit feature of each organisation unit to assign memberships to each group set. You will only be able to assign a single organisation unit at a time however.

section.title: Create an organisation unit
section.para: You add organisation units one by one as either a root unit or a child of a selected organisation unit.

The organisation unit tree to the left represents the current organisation unit hierarchy. If you select a unit in this tree, you will see its children in the list in the middle of the screen. When you have selected an organisation unit in the left side organisation tree, you can also add new children to it.

note.para: The search function displays only exact matches, it is case-insensitive.

section.para: To create a new organisation unit:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit.
Select the organisation unit you want to add the new organisation unit to.
You can locate the organisation unit in the tree by expanding the branches (click on the arrow symbol), or by searching for it by name or code.
Click the yellow plus button.
In the Name field, define the precise name of the organisation unit.
Each organisation unit must have a unique name.
In the Short name field, define a short name for the organisation unit.
Typically, the short name is an abbreviation of the full organisation unit name. This attribute is often used in reports to display the name of the organisation unit, where space is limited.
(Optional) In the Code field, assign a code.
In many countries organisation units are assigned a code.
In the Description field, type a description of the organisation unit.
Select an Opening date.
The opening dates control which organisation units that where existing at a point in time, for example when analysing historical data. This attribute is mandatory.
The default date for opening of organisation units is 1900-01-01, but you can set it to any date even to a date that occurs in the future.
If applicable, select a Closed date.
In the Comment field, enter any additional information that you would like to add.
(Optional) In the URL field, enter a link to an external web site that has additional information about the organisation unit.
Enter contact information:
Contact person
Address
E-mail
Phone number
This information can be vital for facilitating follow-up.
If applicable, enter custom attributes values, for example HR identifier.
If you have added attributes to organisation units, they are visible in the Create new organisation unit pane. You set these attributes in Data Administration > Attribute.
For more information about how you can use attributes, refer to the "Attributes" section.
Click Save.

Coordinates: This field is used to create the maps in the GIS module. Paste in the coordinates of the organisation unit in this field, either a polygon (for organisation units that represent an administrative boundary) or a point (for health facilities). Without this information the GIS module will not work. It might be more efficient to import these coordinates later as a batch job for all organisation units using the import module. See the GIS chapter for more details.
Datasets: Datasets can be assigned to organisation units here. See the chapter on "Data sets" for more detailed information on assigning datasets to organisation units.
Organisation unit groups: Assignments to organisation units group sets can be assigned through the individual drop-down boxes which appear for each group set.

section.title: Create an organisation unit group
section.para: Organisation unit groups lets you classify related organisation units into a common theme. You can for example group all organisation units that are hospitals in an Hospital group.
To create a new organisation unit group:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit Group.
Click the yellow plus button.
Fill in the form:
Name: Provide a precise, unique and descriptive name for the organisation unit group.

Short name: The short name should be less than 25 characters. Typically, the short name is an abbreviation of the full organisation unit name. This attribute is used in certain places in DHIS 2 where space is limited.
Symbol: Select a symbol which will be used to display the organisation unit (points only) when the layer is displayed in the GIS app.
In the organisation tree, click the organisation units you want to add to the organisaiton unit group.
The selected organisation units display in orange.
Datasets: If you assign a dataset to an organisation unit group, all organisation units which are currently assigned to the dataset will be also present in this organisation unit group.
Click Save.

section.title: Create an organisation unit group set
section.para: Organisation unit group sets allows you to create additional classifications of organisation units. The group sets create new dimensions in the analysis applications so that you can make a more detailed data analysis. You an easily filter, organise or aggregate data by groups within a group set.

example.title: Organisation unit group set
example.para: Typcically, one would want to provide analysis based on the ownership of the facilies. In that case one would create a group for each ownership type, for instance MoH, Private and NGO. All facilites in the database must them be classified and assigned to one ond only one of these three groups. Next one would create a group set called Ownership to which the three groups above are assinged, as illustrated in the figure below.

While a group set like "Type" describes a measure dimension, the actual classification are represented by the groups, and the categorisation of an organisation unit through the organisation unit's group memberships. This can be understood as a parallel hierarchy of organisation units with the group set as the root ("Type"), the groups at level 2 (e.g. "Clinic", "Hospital", "Dispensary"), and the actual organisation units at level 3.

listitem.para: You can have any number of organisation unit group sets.
The default organisation unit group sets are Type and Ownership.

An organisation unit group set is always exclusive: an organisation unit can't be a member of more than one group in a group set. Therefore, when creating a new organisation unit, you can only only select a single organisation group membership for each group set.

In the Data Integrity/Data Quality app, you can verify if you've accidently assigned the same organisation unit to multiple groups within the same group set. In this app you will also find information about organisation units that are not members of a complusory organisation unit group set.

You can define whether an organisation unit group set is compulsory or not, which will affect the completeness of the data when analysing data using group sets. Compulsory means that all organisation units must be member of a group in that group set.

section.para: To create an organisation unit group set:

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation Unit Group Set.
Click the yellow plus button.
Fill in the form:
Name: Provide a precise name for the organisation unit group set.
Description: Describe the phenomena the organisation unit group set is measuring or capturing.
If you want that all organisation units are members of a group within this group set, select Compulsory.

example.para: To classify facilites by ownership. Create a organisation unit group set called Ownsership. Include the organisation unit groups Private and PublicIf you want to group all facilites

listitem.para: Organisation group set: Ownership
Organisation unit groups: Private and Public.

example.para: when you have private and public ownshership. You don't want some organisation units not to be classified.

listitem.para: Data dimension
Select organisation unit groups and assign them.

Available organisation unit groups are displayed in the left panel. Organisation unit groups that are currently members of the organisation unit group set are displayed in the right hand panel. Use the arrows to move selected groups between the two lists.
If no groups appear in the list then you must go to Organisation Unit Groups and create new groups first.

note.para: An organisation unit can only be a member of a single organisation unit group within an organisation unit group set.

listitem.para: Click Save.

section.title: Edit organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to edit, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Edit.
Modify the options you want.
Click Save.

section.title: Clone organisation units and other objects
section.para: Cloning a organisation unit can save time when you create many similar organisation units which differ in only a few details.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to clone, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Clone.
Modify the options you want.
Click Save.

section.title: Change sharing settings for organisation unit groups and group sets

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select Organisation unit group or Organisation unit group set.
In the list, find the object you want to modify.
Click the options menu and select Share.
Modify the options you want.
Click Close.

section.title: Delete organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to delete, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to delete.
Click the options menu and select Delete.
Click OK to confirm.

section.title: Display details of organisation units and other objects

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to display, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to view.
To display all metadata about the selected object, click the options menu and select Show details.

section.title: Translate organisation units and other objects
section.para: DHIS 2 provides functionality for translations of database content for example data elements, data element groups, indicators, indicator groups and validation rules. You can translate these elements to any number of locales. A locale represents a specific geographical, political, or cultural region.

tip.para: To activate a translation, go to Apps > Settings > Appearance and select a language.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units.
Select the object type you want to translate, for example organisation unit or organisation unit group.
In the list, find the object you want to translate.
Click the options menu and select Translate.
If you want to translate an organisation unit level, click directly on the Translate icon next to each list item.
Select a locale.
Enter Name, Short name, Description and Form name.
Click Close.

section.title: Assign names to organisation unit levels
section.para: When you add children to an organisation unit, DHIS 2 automatically creates a new organisation unit level if necessary. DHIS 2 also assigns a generic name to this level, for example "level 5". You can replace the genereic name with a contextual name, for example "Country", "Province", "District" or "Health Facility". The contextual names are used in DHIS 2 where levels are referred to. The list of organisation unit levels will take some time to load if the organisation unit hierarchy is very big.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Organisation unit level.
For the lorganisation unit evels you want to change, type a name.
Select offline levels.
Click Save.

section.title: Move organisation units within a hierarchy
section.para: You can move organisation units around in the hierarchy by changing the parent of a selected organisation unit.

listitem.para: Click Apps > Maintenance > Organisation units > Hierarchy operations.
Select the organisation units you want to move:
In the hierarchy tree to the left, select the organisation unit you want to move.
In the hierarchy tree to the right, select where you want to move the organisation unit to.
Repeat selection for all the organisation units you want to move.
Click Move x organisation units, where x stands for the number of organisation units you have selected.
Your changes are immediately reflected in the left side hierarchy tree.
